Really good. Most multiplayer survival games do not have a single player mode and it's way less stressful playing a game like this in comparison to Rust. 
The graphics are great. They are realistic while still being stylized.
The sound design is amazing. The distinct sounds that each insect makes is vary helpful as most of the time they are hidden behind grass.
The base building is very good. Most games with a base building system like this have very poor snapping, this one does not.
This game makes me feel like I am living out a dream, seeing all these bugs up close is awesome. But not the wolf spiders. Those are horrible to look at,  I am very glad they implemented an arachnophobia feature.

I know a fair amount about bugs, here are the things that I have noticed are different about their real life counterparts. Yes I know things need to be gamafied but, 
Wolf spiders do not build webs yet their spawn points often have webs around them anyway.
Larva are not a stand alone species, they are the young of an insect, the Larva enemy does not make sense. 
Lady Birds and lady bugs are the same insect, perhaps a Blister Beetle would make more sense as a replacement for the Lady Bird?
Roly Polys are technically called pill bugs.
The diving bell spider should have the air bubble effect around their abdomen.
Bumble Bees are solitary and would not hang around a picnic table like that, though honey bees would.
Gnat is a catch all term for a variety of small flying bugs the most common of which would be, fruit flies and drain flies.

Ok the ants, black ants are normally associated with the odorous house ant especially in a suburb like this it would make way more sense if the black ants were tier one. The odorous house ant does not have a dedicated soldier class, nor do they really fight all that often. Red ants are generally associated with fire ants, if the red ants are supposed to fire ants, would it not make more sense to switch the two ants tiers? Unless maybe the black ants are supposed to be bullet ants, though in a suburb that would make very little sense.
The lawn mites should be called Clover Mites, though lawn mites is another catch all term.

All that aside I would highly recommend this game.

133473395.review:
I never thought I'd give a positive review for a game with so many bugs!

Okay, now that the obligatory bugs joke is out of the way... this game surprised me in the best way. 

Despite my favorite genre of games being open world survival crafting games with base building, I had been reluctant to give [i]Grounded[/i] a try. I knew the game was "Honey I Shrunk the Kids" as an OWSC game. And that premise didn't seem like one that would draw me in. Likewise, a back yard seemed like an awfully confined setting for an open world. 

But Obsidian knocked it out of the park. The back yard may be small, but it is [b]dense[/b]. There is not a single foot of wasted space. The crafting tree is enjoyable. The base building, while more limited in piece and furniture variety than I would prefer, is solid. I was able to create a player home for myself that I am quite proud of.

I love the whimsy of this game. They had a lot of fun at Obsidian designing this. The backyard has a surprising number of biomes (including a desert setting thanks to the sandbox). There are several "dungeons", but the best is the one with the bees. I won't spoil it for you. And I get a real kick out of the attacks based on the elements of candy.

The combat is fierce and feels great. There are a healthy variety of enemies, many of which have fun combat styles. I also appreciate that there is a respectable number of non-hostile critters spanning all tiers.

There are multiple difficulties and a lot of very good custom game settings. I started playing on medium difficulty, which felt very challenging without being punishing. I don't care about achievements, so it took me about 60 hours to realize that I wasn't getting achievements because I wasn't logged into X-Box. At about the same time, I was hit by the first bug raid on the home I was meticulously crafting. Random home raids are an element of the game that I can appreciate the challenge of, but that I want to remove. So I switched my game to be a custom game where I could turn that off. I made other custom adjustments such as setting the game to pause while in a menu so I could read data entries at my leisure.

I was happy to learn that there is an optional series of castle-defense style raids in the game that I can participate in to experience that element of gameplay even after having disabled the random home raids. 

As of this review, I have done all but the final quest chain. But I am avoiding that because I don't want the game to end. I'm having too much fun in the backyard.

This qualifies as going outside and getting fresh air, right?

111447697.review:
This game keeps surprising.
It may look very basic, but has all the deep mechanics (and more) you'd expect from a survival crafting game. The novelty of seeing everyday backyard items from an insect sized perspective never seems to get old. The map design is beautiful, attention to detail is stunning, there's loads to discover and unlock.

Base building is fluid enough, and allows for plenty of creativity. You'll want to build something nice, and won't be disappointed if you're a house mouse like me. Functional furniture made from plant and insect materials, including framed pictures, lounge chairs, trampolines, basketball hoops... you name it.
You'll require several bases of operation, and there'll be faster ways to get between them eventually. 
Building up high is recommended, ground level is unpredictable.
Daytime looks glorious in HD. Nights are dark and dangerous.

Combat is absolutely savage. You WILL die, alot.
You'll be tempted to explore alot, but are quickly punished for wandering about unprepared. 
Playing with friends is highly recommended.
Comb the backyard's every nook and cranny for new resources to research, and science stuff to unlock better gear.

It's easy to give the game a quick look and a miss, but it rewards if you stick with it.
The insects can sometimes be quite... buggy. ;P It's still in development. Recent content is generous, adding whole new biomes, of which there's plenty.
Not recommended if you're arachnophobic!! The spiders ARE scary, even if you're not (although there is a feature to reduce their spider-like resemblance).

It's pretty difficult to map out a playthrough, because things you need are everywhere, and can be found in any order. The yard is your oyster.
Even though it isn't finished, the game has enough content to keep you quite busy for a while, even without sinking time into building luscious garden palaces.

It's the adventure you always wanted to have as a kid after seeing Honey I Shrunk The Kids.

123701130.review:
An absolute amazing game that is very nearly ruined by absolutely horrific balancing, bugs (no pun intended), and bad collision.

The Good 

There is an amazing amount of content to see and do. When you first start playing the game, it can be quite horrifying. Virtually every bug is incredibly strong, especially at the start of the game, and it definitely adds to the overall vibe of the game. Some of the bugs are honestly terrifying, and towards the start of the game I jumped several times (looking at you wolf spiders).

The level design is fantastic. You can tell they put a lot of thought into where to place objects to let you traverse the map better. This is especially highlighted when you start building zip lines and other objects to help you traverse the map better. 

This is one the best survival games for player progression. There are mutations that are unlocked by using specific types of weapons, or doing specific events. There are also "milk molars" that can be used to upgrade stats like HP, Stamina, food consumption, etc. In addition to the armor / weapon systems, you can end up creating a reasonably unique character, this is especially true for a survival game. 

The base building is also amazing. I spent hours building, rebuilding, and adjusting my base. You unlock new building materials as the game progresses, and the base building mechanics are fun enough that it had be wanting to tear down my base just to make a new one out of the material I just unlocked. There is also a fairly basic base defense mechanic that can have some fun. Though, this is one of the areas that I hope they flush out further. 

The Bad

The game biggest issues is that there is basically no scaling for solo vs. group play. The game is very obviously balanced around group play. Different people will have different opinions on this, but the game is also extremely long. I just can't imagine finding the time to play this game with friends from start to finish. The game can be soloed on the hardest difficulty, but you won't want to. The game needs to scale differently based on the number of players, AND also have a difficulty setting. 

You WILL be cheesing some of the more difficult enemies. Yes yes, I know you're all very awesome at this game and you don't need to cheese but the game can be so incredibly tedious that you will really want to. Gear decays WAY too fast. You will be farming the same parts over and over just to repair the gear you're currently wearing before you end up getting to the end game. Shields can never be repaired with glue, so for most of the game, you will be constantly farming shields parts. This will make the player constantly want to use ranged weapons, because at least your gear isn't breaking every 5 fights. 

On that point, some weapons are just obviously better than others. The greatsword always felt the weakest, shields and bows always felt strong, and maces were somewhere in between. There are different elements that you can imbue your weapons with, and different enemies have different resistances. This seems awesome at first, but then you swiftly realize it becomes a rather tedious and cumbersome mechanic  because you are limited on inventory space. This probably works better with a group of players, but it just ends up being a PITA for solo players. 

Upgrades almost seem worthless as equal tier enemies will basically always two shot you. Once you've upgraded your equipment all the way, which takes a very very long time, you might be able to withstand a couple more hits.

Bosses especially have just absolutely horrible balancing. Some bosses don't have any cool downs on summoning adds. If you get bad RNG, they will literally sit there and spam adds over and over. At one point I had 8 spiders in the room with a boss. Its clear the bosses were also designed for group play. 

Finally, the number one thing that frustrated me the most in this game was the collision and the bugs that came along with it. I was constantly stuck on EVERYTHING in this game. I would have to crouch and bunny hop constantly in this game. When jumping my character would the smallest of obstacles above me and it would send me 10 feet to the left or right. I get that they wanted you to feel like you're in a jungle.  They do a fantastic job at that at making you feel like you're shrunk in someones backyard.  However after 60 hours or so, getting stuck on a tiny pebble while running from a bug, or failing a jump for the 20th time because the game decided to launch me 10 feet, is just insanely frustrating. 

Most enemies also don't follow the same collision rules. Most bugs have a specific attacks that will nearly almost land no matter how far you've run, or what obstacle you've put between you since they started the animation. They clip right through objects and land the attack. Lady bugs and Larvae will literally charge right through solid boulders and hit you. They probably did this in an attempt to mitigate cheesing, but its a very lazy solution. Balancing the game appropriately would have been the better decision. 

Overall If you're a fan of survival games, this one is a no brainer. IMO,  Its definitely in the top 5 games within the survival genre, and  I could see it easily be considered the best once they iron the rest of the kinks.

For the moment, fellow gamer, I'm not going to recommend you pay 30.00 for this game.

Grounded is a visual triumph with tremendous possibility. At best in its current form, you complete the storyline in an hour or less. One making what should have been an epic breakthrough, you are greeted with a prompt telling you that this is as far as they've gone so far in development, but promises there will be more in the future. 

Grounded is like having the very best pringle ever created with perfect flavor and texture, but there's only one in the can. It succeeds in leaving you wanting more- I would have eve bought new region unlocks it is that immersive- but, the game just ends. You can continue to build, explore and hunt, but this is simply a demo- and prior to playing 30 dollars, be aware it is a demo and that while the experience is an an amazing, albeit short-lived one, it is not a fully developed game in early access for polish, it has the opening chapter of the story, and you're done. It is not worth more than 10 dollars in it's current state. 

I am really frustrated with developers releasing demos at full retail cost. The concept of Early Access has become a fierce cash grab and enables developers to produce minimal content on their own terms, usually very slowly while they harvest money from the hopeful expectations of players. for may gamers, the cost of this game costs two hours of work- and from investment, they get an hour of content. 

 When the game is beyond a demo phase, I wil likely change this review, but I can't in good faith justify 30 dollars for an unfinished game- even leverage the all-to-common "Early Access" excuse often used. However, this is will most certainly be a phenomenal game when finished.

Warning: At the time of writing, it is *clearly* early access (as advertised). If you get annoyed by missing content, bugs, and crashes, then you might want to wait for a more complete experience.

It's the well-known genre of basebuilding/survival, where you can build a base, explore, and gradually get better resources and equipment. It works well. Both alone and with friends.

What I think makes it stand out is the visuals. It is a unique setting – and it also looks great!

Pros:
* Looks great
* Plays well
* Original setting
* Fun both alone and with friends
* A ton of potential here. There is so much fun things they can easily implement and build on this.
* Scary spiders, but they have an arachnophobia-setting you can use to dial back their appearance to something less scary!

Cons:
* Very Early Access. It just released. This means there is a chance you will run into frequent crashes or gamebreaking bugs requiring you to start over or reload an older save – although it has not been a major issue for me.
* A LOT of content still missing. It is clear more is planned. There are locked doors to several bases/labs that you can't enter, and several areas are literally marked in-game as "under construction". Missing enemy types. Missing story.
* Bad pathfinding for the Ai enemies. It is often trivial to make them get stuck somewhere silly so you can just slowly take them down with a ton of weak arrows from a safe distance. I hope they improve this, as it makes some things a bit easier than it should be.

My recommendation is based on the assumption that they will actively keep building and improving on the game; especially adding more content and story.

Update November 2020:  
There has been a major update filling in one more area of the map (the pond). A whole bunch of other smaller improvements to the game, so it is gradually improving.

I like finding all the random objects scattered about the yard, it's fun to see what you'll find next, although I do wish they had more of a purpose besides landmarks.

Some things I think that could use some work/fixing:
- When me or my friends net drops even the slightest, it kicks the person who joins the game. I've been kicked from the game maybe 20 times today.
- When the host jumps into a spider web and then breaks it, they are stuck suspended in the air and not able to get out unless they reload the game.
- The joiner can't see the proper durability on their items when rejoining. They are all stuck on full even if the item is broken.
- The meat spoilage is way too fast. Food is the one thing you need when waking up, and all the meat is spoiled overnight so I rarely have any food besides things that give me the smallest amount of hunger refilled.
- I think spiders could use a rework, they hit super hard and there are way too many of them around for how powerful they are and the armor you make before spider armor does not protect you nearly enough to even fight spiders unless you want to shoot 50 arrows into them from afar.
- Building feels very -iffy too. It was really frustrating to try to build until we found clay foundations, so I think it is a bit better. But I'd still like to see the building be much easier since some of the things are really hard to place and spaz out all over the place.

Update after playing a little longer:
-Spiders aren't too bad if you've got a friend to help kill them, especially the Golden Orbweavers. Blocking is pretty hugely important to fighting stronger things. But I still think there's a lot of them.

92441362.review:
Grounded is a very memorable childhood movie, Honey I Shrunk the Kids turned into a game.  It starts with a nice mystery to  how you ended in your current predicament.  You wake up from a suitcase with 5 perfectly human sized cut outs with some form of breathing apparatus but there's only 4 of you currently (you and 3 other coop players) shoved underground.

As you explore, discover many landmarks and biomes along with the dangers, wonders and new materials that come with it.  The crafting is quite extensive for structures with some miner hiccups here and there.  You're mostly building similar the shapes of Fortnite but with a more whimsical Lilliput style construction.  There's a lot of potential here from what I can see with the early access.  Armor sets have stat bonuses so mixing and matching might not be the best but some individual pieces also have innate bonuses as well.  If they have a diverse range of armors, there is potential for a lot of different builds.

Combat is fairly tight and timing is important for blocking.  Dodging is not as active as you can outrun most enemies or at least weave through terrain or use vertical movement to your advantage.

Only con so far that I can think of is there is in-game currency called raw science.  You can acquire them through playing the game, exploration or doing daily quest but it is quite the grind for it and learning new recipes and blueprints are quite expensive for a few.  I hope they reduce the price down a bit as I didn't even bother to unlock ladders for example because it was priced at 3500 RS, the daily quest pays between 100-500 and take quite some time to do.

136762924.review:
Is it scary? Yes. Whoever designed the wolf spider sounds must have been giggling like an evil villain the entire time.
Is it gory? No. Not unless you count bug splatters, at least.
Is it cute? Yes, most of the time. The sleeping bee sounds are my favorite. The art direction is really standout here, as well — the 90's motif helps keep everything colorful and upbeat. Lighting and fog work together to hone in on the ambiance of a given area as well, creating peaceful dawns and foreboding nights.
Is it fun? I think so. The crafting takes a while to get the hang of, and I think that the multiplayer aspect would greatly improve my experience. (Alas, everyone I've asked to play is too afraid of bugs to join me.) That said, I still really enjoy the game mechanics. It never feels too difficult to understand what I'm supposed to be doing. Certain things can be a grind, especially playing solo, but the various factors at play with roving insects keep it from feeling monotonous.

73513343.review:
I have to write this review for all those bad reviews that are not true. 

Firstly anyone who says they completed the story is lying. The first initial quest does take maybe 30 mins if you focus on it but that is NOT the complete story and just the tutorial. You have to collect better resources and kill stronger bugs to be able to unlock more areas where you will find more quests and learn more about the story. This all requires better tier tools that requires time to get.

Secondly those who are saying multiplayer does not work is also lying. Currently there is no way to join other servers but you can join your friends who host a multiplayer game. You must do this through Xbox friend list which is free to make an account and join them that way. This Is not ideal and with time I see it being fixed however being an early access we are lucky we have multiplayer. Also note there is in game voice chat which again is lucky to have for a early access game. 

If either of those reasons are holding you back from getting the game, don't let it. There is a lot of game play for being a early access game. I have 7 hours on the game and have yet to scratch the surface it seems with so many hidden quests and mysterious doors that you need to find a way to open. Also remember this is a early access game so the game will not run as a full released game and there will be more content added guaranteed. If you can get a couple of friends to play the game with you then it will be even better and much more enjoyable.

74374934.review:
A quick review and feedback

+ An interesting open world. Many places have an interesting multiple-layer design including underground and over the ground (on the tree) layer. With abundant diversity on the map and great reward, it keeps players interested in exploration.

+ Unique, beautiful micro-photograph like graphics

- Not enough contents in the story for now

- Key binding is a hot mess. Even the same action of confirmation, in different menus, you have to use different keys like LMB, Space, W, R, etc. Just make a universal binding for all menus.

- No hitbox. Hitting in the body or head deals the same damage.

- Lack of flexibility in building. For example, players cannot customize the length of stairs or floors, resulting some awkward situations like leaving a hole on the ground.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2198778795

- Flaws in building.It is extremely difficult to build stairs between two platforms or build walls between two existing layers. Even if I manage to do it, I cannot do it perfectly. Like here, somehow I have to jump on it instead of walking.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2198778287

- The game is not physic, which is fine by me. However, sometimes I cannot build things on a very reasonable spot. And very often it just keeps blinking between red and blue, like even the game can’t tell if you can build things at this spot.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2198779074

- Objects going through other objects. It is so often that almost annoys me.  See these examples.

Spider legs went through the wood. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2198784035

Clovers grew inside my house.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2198779724

Walls on the lower floor went through the ground
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2198779965

Floors waiting for construction sunk into underground (twice, all with triangle floors)
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2198783485

Grass I chopped down sunk into underground, later I found them laying inside the underground tunnel. But more often, they just reappeared after a while.


Overall, building mechanics work fine with small, regular shape buildings. But once you build some giant, irregular shape buildings with complex architectural structures, it really sucks. 

It does have potential and I had fun playing it. But please fix these issues.

104480889.review:
This game is an extremely immersive for a sandbox survival.

It's like being in Honey I shrunk the kids but looks better.

Sound effects are on point, the chase/battle music is intense.
Night time is very dark until the moon comes out. 
  
For a kid friendly looking game, it has a lot of fear induced adrenaline moments.

Great graphics, solid building interface for early access. 
Game physics and atmosphere are impressive. 

Fun game to play, I highly recommend it.
